description: Digital health is a broad overarching term encompassing digital tools, technologies and services that connect and empower people and populations to manage health and wellness. Digital health varies from relatively established areas such as communication between a patient and a doctor through telemedicine to newly emerging areas such as the use of computer science in big data and artificial intelligence to enhance the accuracy of the diagnostic processes or predicting patient outcomes. In the recent years, digital health became an inevitable part of healthcare providing personalized healthcare.This course will introduce undergraduate students to the landscape of digital health technology and the application of digital health data. Digital devices can be helpful for individuals to monitor their health through wearable devices, mobile application monitoring and home systems. These devices can have benefits to patient care and improve health. This course will provide students with the basic architecture of digital health from digital devices and data platforms, computing and data science and artificial intelligence. Students will also acquire experience of digital innovation from user and stakeholder engagement. Students will start with an overview of digital health and then discuss research articles on social media data for disease management, new forms of health data from wearable devices and mobile APPs, and discussion on the big data and the application of artificial intelligence. Students will be divided into different teams to prepare a pitching presentation after they attend lessons from case studies and stakeholder sharing. Feedbacks and comments will be given by a team of judgement panel in the final presentation. Finally, they will be able to describe the basic components of digital health and understand the application of digital health technology through experiential learning in a pitching presentation.

title: Resilience Building in Professional and Personal Development I
description: Medical schools strive to educate knowledgeable, caring and professional physicians. The growing interest in empathy, wellness and resilience has fuelled the design and implementation of structured educational programmes worldwide to cultivate empathy, especially when there is a globally increasing trend in professional burnout among undergraduates and resident trainees. Empathy in the medical setting includes appreciating the patient's emotions and the expression of that awareness. Empathy is an essential learning objective that can be cultivated. Empathy brings about patient satisfaction, promotes adherence to medical recommendations and good clinical outcomes, and more importantly, professional satisfaction. A key component of empathy is reflective capacity. Fostering reflective capacity within medical education helps develop critical thinking skills, inform clinical reasoning, and enhance professionalism among trainees. The development of reflective capacity is conducive to effective feedback in medical education and is an essential aspect of self-regulated and lifelong learning. Failure to reflect on one's thinking processes, including a critical examination of one's assumptions, beliefs, and conclusions, was recently described as a cognitive component of "physician overconfidence," a contributing cause of diagnostic error in medicine. Reflection is not necessarily intuitive, especially in students at the initial stages of their medical careers. The over-arching aim of the course is to nurture and consolidate the key soft skills of an effective doctor and a healthy resilient personality through the development of reflective capacity and empathy.The course is delivered in progressive stages to build reflective capacity and empathy in specific professional developmental contexts. The four building blocks, as outlined below, will be emphasized in different years. The building blocks will be progressively built and integrated over the curriculum from years 2 to 4.1. Empathic Engagement (Year 2)2. Doctor and Society (Year 3)3. Doctor and Self- Reflection in Practice (Year 4)4. Doctor and Profession (Year 4)The four components encompass the core values of a healthy and competent doctor who can foster a therapeutic alliance with patients, appreciate and reflect the meaning of work, be a team player, and connect with the public and society.Attendance to the empathic engagement workshop is mandatory.
outcome: After completing the course, students should be able to:1.     describe the key elements of an effective and empathic engagement with patients (affective, cognitive, somatic);2.     appreciate aspects of distressed or distancing empathy leading to over-arousal (sympathetic distress) or aversion;3.     appraise contexts and factors leading to empathic failure, distressed or distancing empathy;4.     understand the neural network of empathy and how empathy (towards self and others, in personal and professional contexts) translates into sustainable professional practice and life satisfaction;5.     understand the importance of cultivating reflective practice to maintain effective empathy in professional context; and6.     understand and practice the process of reflective practice: reflection on content and process (context, self), reflection in action (real-time awareness), reflection on action (retrospective).
syllabus: The course comprises three parts that utilize multimodal and multimedia means, which all aim to engage students' active participation and self-reflection.Topics: Empathy in clinical practiceLearning Contents: What is empathy? What is the difference between A.I. and a clinician who loses empathy or is defeated by empathy? (Clinical, psychological and neuroscience perspectives) Virtual-reality assisted experiential learning—knowing how your patients feelTopics: Self-practice/Self-reflection approach- adjustment to the new learning environment and develop healthy self-care habits alongside professional development.Learning Contents: Exploring your typology as a learner and strategies for effective learning in the professional curriculum. Exploring perfectionism and the common cognitive schema when striving for excellence/ survival in the professional curriculum. Understanding your stress response and fostering self-compassion. Introduction to mindfulness practice.Topics: Mental Health Awareness & self-care for DoctorsLearning Contents: Burnout in professional practice; Common mental health problems in young people and adaptive strategies. Introduction to Mental Health First Aid. Resources for fostering psychological wellness and for crisis support in our community.Workshop and Learning activities:The practical workshops will utilize multimodal, and multimedia means. The scope of activities includes: theme-based didactic lectures (pre-recorded online lectures to honor a more personalized learning pace and allow a protected personal space for deeper immersion into the topics). self-assessment on psychological burnout, learning and coping style. VR-assisted experiential learning. self-study on suggested references and active self-reflection on the reading materials.

description: This course describes key elements in an effective doctor-patient relationship and in effective communications with the community. The course also introduces students to the biological, social and ethical aspects of health and illness. The course has two components. Part I is a series of visits with a medical doctor to observe, understand and acquire insight into the patient presentation and the role of a family doctor in the community and the doctor-patient relationship. Part II is longitudinal follow-up of a family with a new born baby in order to observe and interact with a family with a newborn to be able to understand and describe influences on child development e.g. socio-economic background of the family, health beliefs and practices, family adjustment to the newborn, social support, community support, assessment of milestones etc. This course is delivered by a series of lectures, small group tutorials, presentations, visits to family doctors in the community, and interviews with a family on wards and in the community.
outcome: After completing this course, students should be able to:1) describe the patient's presentation by integrating biological, psychological and social aspects of illness;2) describe the role of the family doctor and health professionals in the community and the key elements of an effective doctor patient relationship;3) interact and gather information from the family regarding pregnancy, childbirth and child care;4) describe the health, social and developmental issues of a child from birth to 3 months; and5) demonstrate skills in reflective writing

title: Resilience Building in Professional and Personal Development III
description: Medical schools strive to educate knowledgeable, caring and professional physicians. The course is delivered in progressive stages to build reflective capacity and empathy in specific professional developmental contexts. The four building blocks as outlined below will be emphasized in different years. The building blocks will be progressively built and integrated over the curriculum from years 2 to 4.1. Medical students are also expected to explore self and teamwork in a clinical environment with a good sense of professionalism. A clinical medical setting is a teamwork environment with multidisciplinary professionals, e.g., doctors, nurses, pharmacists, physiotherapists, who must work together, communicate frequently, and have a common goal to care for the patients. The World Health Organization (WHO) also recommends medical students learn the principles of teamwork in their training. Moreover, nowadays, the work duty of a doctor is heavily loaded, physically and emotionally. The development of regular self-reflection in practice would help the students enhance resilience in managing stress. In this course, Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) will be used to help the students reflect on how their values, needs, and personality traits greatly influence the helping process and style. Apart from MBTI, Mindfulness is recognized by the leading Medical Schools worldwide as a beneficial practice for their students and residents. Mindfulness is cultivated to promote self-care, self-awareness, and empathy with the ultimate aim of mutually improving the well–being of doctors-in-training and for the long-term patient care with good quality. Mindfulness and Cognitive techniques for medical students.

description: This course provides 9 weeks of integrated teaching in Community and Family Medicine. In Community Medicine, three major areas are covered: Epidemiology and Biostatistics, Public Health Medicine, and Occupation and Environmental Medicine. The principles and practice of public health, the application of epidemiological study methods, and the prevention and control of communicable, non-communicable and occupational diseases are introduced to students. In addition to lectures, clinical attachments, interactive/practical sessions, field visits, group work, and presentations in seminars and tutorials are utilised to facilitate learning. The clinical clerkship in Family Medicine teaches practical family medicine skills and equips students with the understanding and ability to diagnose and manage common medical conditions that present in primary care settings. Throughout the clerkship, students are taught skills in making differential diagnoses of presenting symptoms, prioritisation of multiple medical conditions and investigations and management of common medical problems in the community. Students also gain exposure to the basic principles and practice of family medicine, i.e., providing primary, comprehensive, holistic and continuing person centred care. The clinical clerkship consists of online teaching and case based seminars, clinical team based learning workshops, clinical attachments to private family medicine doctors, Hospital Authority clinics and community health centres and health care providers for vulnerable populations. To facilitate learning, role playing in workshops and clinical enhanced skills training are provided. Facilities utilised for this clinical teaching include the University Family Medicine Clinics, and Family Medicine clinics run by Hospital Authority and private practitioners, both in public and private settings throughout Hong Kong.
outcome: By the end of the Module, students are expected to be able to:  1.    apply the principles and methods of studying health problems in population groups;  2.    list the major causes of mortality and morbidity in Hong Kong, including communicable and non-communicable diseases, and describe strategies of prevention and control of these problems;  3.    describe the organization of health care system, health services and medical practice in Hong Kong;  4.    describe the principles and practice of occupational and environmental medicine;  5.    apply the principles and methods of epidemiology in health care practice;  6.    adopt a person centred family medicine approach to clinical consultation and evidence based medicine;  7.    apply a hypothetical deductive approach in diagnoses formulation, demonstrate management of presenting condition and deliver first line management of common acute and chronic problems in primary care;  8.    counsel patients using a lifestyle behavioural approach to promote health in community settings; and9.    explain the role and interactions of health and social issues and resources in the community.

Use competently the clinical method to identify and plan to resolve clinical problems through:  • reliable, relevant and sensitive history taking, relating effectively to parents and children;  • thorough, accurate and gentle physical examination;  • concise evaluation of the presenting clinical problem;  • orderly planning of any further diagnostic procedures which might be indicated to establish a diagnosis;  • appreciation of the PRINCIPLES of treatment (including the roles of other health professionals, e.g., speech therapists, physiotherapists, social workers, clinical psychologists in management);  • understanding the principles underlying FOLLOW-UP assessment in order to appreciate the natural or assisted course of a clinical problem;  • awareness of the psycho-social consequences (the impact of illness on behaviour, education, family life) of illness and its simple medico-legal consequences; and  • appreciation of a broad, holistic and sensitive outlook towards the total health of individuals and communities.  4. Demonstrate skill in communicating with a child, parents and fellow professional workers, including traits of empathy, patience, kindness and counselling ability.  5. Provide at the bedside an orderly presentation of a clinical problem. 6. Appreciate the manner in which paediatric problems, their management and prevention interrelate with the practices of other disciplines, especially community medicine, psychiatry and obstetrics.

title: Clinical Ethics I
description: This course introduces ethical dilemma arising from some special circumstances in the clinical practice of each discipline. In the Family Medicine module, students will learn about issues in common clinical encounter, including presentation of serious conditions at early stage, disclosure of information, breaking the bad news, patient autonomy, confidentiality, conflict of interests, duty to third parties, and dealing with clinical errors. Through small group teachings, students will be able to discuss challenges and forumulate possible solutions.Main objective: To teach medical students the potential medico-legal pitfalls and the ethical dilemmas in daily family practice as family physicians will be asked to undertake various tasks not within the boundary of conventional healthcare setting.Specific objective: To teach Year 5 medical students of The Chinese University of Hong Kong the potential medico-legal pitfalls in daily family practice and the ethical dilemmas in daily practice. It will build on the teaching in year 4.Students must read the note and refresh what they have learnt from Bioethics course especially in Year 4 before coming to class for meaningful interactive discussion.In the Obstetrics and Gynaecology module, students will learn about ethical issues through the interactive student forum and seminar, such as termination of pregnancy, reproductive autonomy in the face to emerging technologies, as well as obstetricians' role in the decision-making between pregnant women and the potential human — fetus.In the Paediatrics module, students will learn about bioethical considerations that paediatricians face while treating children for health conditions. For children, unlike for adult patients, healthcare decisions are often made by someone other than the person to be treated, i.e. by the parents/primary carers. Issues of patient confidentiality, consent for treatment, and child protection require the treating doctor to be aware of the specific needs and desires of the child, and to be able to respect and adequately address situations when the child's and parents' views and needs diverge. In the Psychiatry module, students will learn about common and unique bioethical considerations that psychiatry faces while treating patients with mental health conditions, such as patient confidentiality, consent for treatment in psychiatric illness, and capacity determination.In addition, students are required to attend the annual Lanson Lecture hosted by the CUHK Centre for Bioethics.

title: Clinical Ethics II
description: The MED6 curriculum emphasises clinical teaching through hospital rotations in medicine, surgery, and other sub-specialised disciplines, including anaesthesia, intensive care, clinical oncology, ear, nose and throat, emergency medicine, cardiothoracic surgery, neurosurgery, and orthopaedics and trauma. Alongside the essential medical knowledge required for everyday care, students must also learn to navigate the complex and multifaceted landscape of healthcare relationships among all stakeholders and the ethical challenges that arise within it.Parallel to clinical teaching, the MED6 Clinical Ethics II course will enable students to apply the moral reasoning principles in healthcare delivery. The curricular design leverages clinical experiences to promote ethical decision-making and the resolution of dilemmas. In doing so, students will develop tangible critical thinking skills to prevent and resolve doctor-patient conflicts, which is a crucial step in the transition to becoming medical professionals. Students are expected to identify the ethical issues, resolve the dilemmas through an ethical reasoning process, and implement their decisions through communication with patients or their surrogates.

description: The Senior Medical Clerkship consists of two ten-week modules, referred to as Medicine A and Medicine B. Medicine A consists of attachments to the medical wards in Princess Margaret Hospital, North District Hospital, Shatin Hospital, Our Lady of Maryknoll Hospital, and Prince of Wales Hospital as well as Clinical Skills Lab and one week of Assistant Intern (AI) Programme shadowing Medical Officers at the Prince of Wales Hospital. Students are attached to each of the above hospitals/unit in rotation. Medicine B involves attachments to medical wards under the supervision of the Department of Medicine and Therapeutics, Department of Clinical Oncology, and Accident and Emergency Medicine Academic Unit as well as a one week of AI Programme shadowing Interns in the Prince of Wales Hospital. Students are attached to each of the above Departments in rotation in order to learn by daily clinical contact with patients in the respective wards. Students are encouraged to clerk patients and present during subspecialty rounds, and to follow patients’ progress during their hospital stay. Subspecialty teaching sessions are also held every Wednesday throughout the two modules. Students are attached to subspecialty activities and outpatient clinics during their respective rotations. Bedside teaching of clinical skills is arranged in small groups twice weekly. All students in these medical rotations are expected to attend medical grand rounds every Wednesday.A total of two-week AI Programme shadowing with one-week AI Programme shadowing Medical Officers is integrated into Medicine A module while a one-week AI Programme shadowing Interns is integrated into Medicine B module. Students shadow the frontline doctors to learn and experience daily clinical work with both inpatients and outpatients. Requiring active participation in clinical activities under close supervision by the frontline doctors, the programme is designed to help students develop core competencies as medical professionals. The AI Programme aims to nurture self-initiative, sense of responsibility, stress coping strategies, communication skills and social responsibility through experiential learning in actual clinical settings.Small group tutorials during both clerkships as well as during AI are provided in order to further develop students' communication skills within clinical and professional settings. This includes presenting in medical rounds, writing patients' scripts and referrals, having communications with lay public concerning medical matters, handling complaints and bad news, organizing and presenting literature or decision making in clinical conferences. These skills are assessed formally in the end-of-module examinations and are also an obligatory component of final year graduating examinations. Multidisciplinary integrative sessions are maintained throughout this course.
